title: Europe
text:
Europe is a <a href="continent">continent</a> which is also recognised as part of <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>, located entirely in the <a href="Northern%20Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a> and mostly in the <a href="Eastern%20Hemisphere">Eastern Hemisphere</a>. Comprising the westernmost peninsulas of the <a href="Continent">continental landmass</a> of Eurasia, it shares the continental landmass of <a href="Afro-Eurasia">Afro-Eurasia</a> with both <a href="Asia">Asia</a> and <a href="Africa">Africa</a>. It is bordered by the <a href="Arctic%20Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a> to the north, the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the west, the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south and Asia to the east. Europe is commonly considered to be <a href="Borders%20of%20the%20continents%23Europe%20and%20Asia">separated from Asia</a> by the <a href="drainage%20divide">watershed</a> of the <a href="Ural%20Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>, the <a href="Ural%20%28river%29">Ural River</a>, the <a href="Caspian%20Sea">Caspian Sea</a>, the <a href="Greater%20Caucasus">Greater Caucasus</a>, the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> and the waterways of the <a href="Turkish%20Straits">Turkish Straits</a>. Although much of this border is over land, Europe is almost always recognised as its own continent because of its great physical size and the weight of its history and traditions.
Europe covers about , or 2% of the Earth's surface (6.8% of land area), making it the second-smallest continent (using the <a href="Continent%23Number">seven-continent model</a>). Politically, Europe is divided into about <a href="List%20of%20sovereign%20states%20and%20dependent%20territories%20in%20Europe">fifty sovereign states</a>, of which <a href="Russia">Russia</a> is the <a href="List%20of%20European%20countries%20by%20area">largest</a> and <a href="European%20countries%20by%20population">most populous</a>, spanning 39% of the continent and comprising 15% of its population. Europe had a <a href="Demographics%20of%20Europe">total population</a> of about million (about 10% of the <a href="world%20population">world population</a>) in . The <a href="European%20climate">European climate</a> is largely affected by warm Atlantic currents that temper winters and summers on much of the continent, even at <a href="latitudes">latitudes</a> along which the climate in Asia and <a href="North%20America">North America</a> is severe. Further from the sea, seasonal differences are more noticeable than close to the coast.
European culture is the root of <a href="Western%20civilisation">Western civilisation</a>, which traces its lineage back to <a href="ancient%20Greece">ancient Greece</a> and <a href="ancient%20Rome">ancient Rome</a>. The <a href="fall%20of%20the%20Western%20Roman%20Empire">fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> in 476 AD and the subsequent <a href="Migration%20Period">Migration Period</a> marked the end of Europe's <a href="ancient%20history">ancient history</a>, and the beginning of the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>. <a href="Renaissance%20humanism">Renaissance humanism</a>, <a href="Renaissance%20exploration">exploration</a>, <a href="Renaissance%20art">art</a> and <a href="Renaissance%20science">science</a> led to the <a href="modern%20era">modern era</a>. Since the <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>, started by Portugal and Spain, Europe played a predominant role in global affairs. Between the 16th and 20th centuries, <a href="List%20of%20former%20European%20colonies">European powers colonised</a> at various times the <a href="Americas">Americas</a>, almost all of Africa and <a href="Oceania">Oceania</a>, and the majority of Asia.
The <a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, the subsequent <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> and the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> shaped the continent culturally, politically and economically from the end of the 17th century until the first half of the 19th century. The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, which began in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> at the end of the 18th century, gave rise to radical economic, cultural and social change in <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a> and eventually the wider world. Both <a href="world%20war">world war</a>s took place for the most part in Europe, contributing to a decline in Western European dominance in world affairs by the mid-20th century as the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and the United States took prominence. During the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>, Europe was divided along the <a href="Iron%20Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> between <a href="NATO">NATO</a> in the West and the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> in the East, until the <a href="revolutions%20of%201989">revolutions of 1989</a>, <a href="fall%20of%20the%20Berlin%20Wall">fall of the Berlin Wall</a> and the <a href="dissolution%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>.
In 1949, the <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a> was founded with the idea of unifying Europe to achieve common goals and prevent future wars. Further <a href="European%20integration">European integration</a> by some states led to the formation of the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> (EU), a separate political entity that lies between a <a href="confederation">confederation</a> and a <a href="federation">federation</a>. The EU originated in Western Europe but has been <a href="Enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">expanding eastward</a> since the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991. The currency of most countries of the European Union, the <a href="euro">euro</a>, is the most commonly used among Europeans; and the EU's <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a> abolishes border, and immigration controls between most of its member states and some non-member states. There exists a political movement favouring the evolution of the European Union into a <a href="United%20States%20of%20Europe">single federation encompassing much of the continent</a>.
Name.
In classical <a href="Greek%20mythology">Greek mythology</a>, <a href="Europa%20%28consort%20of%20Zeus%29">Europa</a> (, ) was a <a href="Phoenicia">Phoenicia</a>n princess. One view is that her name derives from the <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Ancient Greek</a> elements () 'wide, broad', and (, <a href="Genitive%20case"></a> , ) 'eye, face, countenance', hence their composite would mean 'wide-gazing' or 'broad of aspect'. "Broad" has been an <a href="epithet">epithet</a> of Earth herself in the reconstructed <a href="Proto-Indo-European%20religion">Proto-Indo-European religion</a> and the poetry devoted to it. An alternative view is that of <a href="Robert%20S.%20P.%20Beekes">Robert Beekes</a>, who has argued in favour of a Pre-Indo-European origin for the name, explaining that a derivation from would yield a different toponym than Europa. Beekes has located toponyms related to that of Europa in the territory of ancient Greece, and localities such as that of <a href="Europus%20%28Almopia%29">Europos</a> in <a href="Macedonia%20%28ancient%20kingdom%29">ancient Macedonia</a>.
There have been attempts to connect to a Semitic term for "west", this being either <a href="Akkadian%20language">Akkadian</a> meaning 'to go down, set' (said of the sun) or <a href="Phoenician%20language">Phoenician</a> 'evening, west', which is at the origin of <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> and <a href="Hebrew%20language">Hebrew</a> . <a href="Martin%20Litchfield%20West">Martin Litchfield West</a> stated that "phonologically, the match between Europa's name and any form of the Semitic word is very poor", while Beekes considers a connection to Semitic languages improbable.
Most major world languages use words derived from or "Europa" to refer to the continent. Chinese, for example, uses the word , which is an abbreviation of the transliterated name ("zhōu" means "continent"); a similar Chinese-derived term is also sometimes used in Japanese such as in the Japanese name of the European Union, , despite the <a href="katakana">katakana</a> being more commonly used. In some Turkic languages, the originally Persian name ('land of the <a href="Franks">Franks</a>') is used casually in referring to much of Europe, besides official names such as or .
Definition.
Contemporary definition.
The prevalent definition of Europe as a geographical term has been in use since the mid-19th century.
Europe is taken to be bounded by large bodies of water to the north, west and south; Europe's limits to the east and north-east are usually taken to be the <a href="Ural%20Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>, the <a href="Ural%20River">Ural River</a> and the <a href="Caspian%20Sea">Caspian Sea</a>; to the south-east, the <a href="Caucasus%20Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a>, the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> and the waterways connecting the Black Sea to the Mediterranean Sea.
Islands are generally grouped with the nearest continental landmass, hence <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> is considered to be part of Europe, while the nearby island of Greenland is usually assigned to <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, although politically belonging to Denmark. Nevertheless, there are some exceptions based on sociopolitical and cultural differences. Cyprus is closest to <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia (or Asia Minor)</a>, but is considered part of Europe politically and it is a member state of the EU. Malta was considered an island of <a href="Northwest%20Africa">Northwest Africa</a> for centuries, but now it is considered to be part of Europe as well.
"Europe", as used specifically in <a href="British%20English">British English</a>, may also refer to <a href="Continental%20Europe">Continental Europe</a> exclusively.
The term "continent" usually implies the <a href="physical%20geography">physical geography</a> of a large land mass completely or almost completely surrounded by water at its borders. However, the Europe-Asia part of the border is somewhat arbitrary and inconsistent with this definition because of its partial adherence to the Ural and Caucasus Mountains rather than a series of partly joined waterways suggested by cartographer <a href="Herman%20Moll">Herman Moll</a> in 1715. These water divides extend with a few relatively small interruptions (compared to the aforementioned mountain ranges) from the Turkish straits running into the Mediterranean Sea to the upper part of the <a href="Ob%20River">Ob River</a> that drains into the <a href="Arctic%20Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a>. Prior to the adoption of the current convention that includes mountain divides, the border between Europe and Asia had been redefined several times since its first conception in <a href="classical%20antiquity">classical antiquity</a>, but always as a series of rivers, seas and straits that were believed to extend an unknown distance east and north from the Mediterranean Sea without the inclusion of any mountain ranges.
The current division of Eurasia into two continents now reflects <a href="East%E2%80%93West%20dichotomy">East-West</a> cultural, linguistic and ethnic differences which vary on a spectrum rather than with a sharp dividing line. The geographic border between Europe and Asia does not follow any state boundaries and now only follows a few bodies of water. Turkey is generally considered a <a href="List%20of%20transcontinental%20countries">transcontinental country</a> divided entirely by water, while <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> are only partly divided by waterways. France, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom are also transcontinental (or more properly, intercontinental, when oceans or large seas are involved) in that their main land areas are in Europe while pockets of their territories are located on other <a href="continents">continents</a> separated from Europe by large bodies of water. Spain, for example, has territories south of the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> namely <a href="Ceuta">Ceuta</a> and <a href="Melilla">Melilla</a> which are parts of <a href="Africa">Africa</a>, and share a border with Morocco. According to the current convention, Georgia and Azerbaijan are transcontinental countries where waterways have been completely replaced by mountains as the divide between continents.
History of the concept.
Early history.
The first recorded usage of "Eurṓpē" as a geographic term is in the <a href="Homeric%20Hymn">Homeric Hymn</a> to <a href="Delian%20Apollo">Delian Apollo</a>, in reference to the western shore of the <a href="Aegean%20Sea">Aegean Sea</a>. As a name for a part of the known world, it is first used in the 6th century BCE by <a href="Anaximander">Anaximander</a> and <a href="Hecataeus%20of%20Miletus">Hecataeus</a>. Anaximander placed the boundary between Asia and Europe along the Phasis River (the modern <a href="Rioni%20River">Rioni River</a> on the territory of <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>) in the Caucasus, a convention still followed by <a href="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> in the 5th century BCE. Herodotus mentioned that the world had been divided by unknown persons into three parts, Europe, Asia and Libya (Africa), with the <a href="Nile">Nile</a> and the Phasis forming their boundaries—though he also states that some considered the <a href="Don%20River%20%28Russia%29">River Don</a>, rather than the Phasis, as the boundary between Europe and Asia. Europe's eastern frontier was defined in the 1st century by geographer <a href="Strabo">Strabo</a> at the River Don. The "<a href="Jubilees">Book of Jubilees</a>" described the continents as the lands given by <a href="Noah">Noah</a> to his three sons; Europe was defined as stretching from the <a href="Pillars%20of%20Hercules">Pillars of Hercules</a> at the <a href="Strait%20of%20Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a>, separating it from <a href="Northwest%20Africa">Northwest Africa</a>, to the Don, separating it from Asia.
The convention received by the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> and surviving into modern usage is that of the <a href="Roman%20era">Roman era</a> used by Roman-era authors such as <a href="Posidonius">Posidonius</a>, <a href="Strabo">Strabo</a> and <a href="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>, who took the Tanais (the modern Don River) as the boundary.
The term "Europe" is first used for a cultural sphere in the <a href="Carolingian%20Renaissance">Carolingian Renaissance</a> of the 9th century. From that time, the term designated the sphere of influence of the <a href="Western%20Church">Western Church</a>, as opposed to both the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> churches and to the <a href="Islamic%20world">Islamic world</a>.
A cultural definition of Europe as the lands of <a href="Christendom">Latin Christendom</a> coalesced in the 8th century, signifying the new cultural condominium created through the confluence of Germanic traditions and Christian-Latin culture, defined partly in contrast with <a href="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> and <a href="Islam">Islam</a>, and limited to northern <a href="Iberia">Iberia</a>, the British Isles, France, Christianised western Germany, the Alpine regions and northern and central Italy. The concept is one of the lasting legacies of the <a href="Carolingian%20Renaissance">Carolingian Renaissance</a>: "Europa" often figures in the letters of Charlemagne's court scholar, <a href="Alcuin">Alcuin</a>.
Modern definitions.
The question of defining a precise eastern boundary of Europe arises in the Early Modern period, as the eastern extension of <a href="Tsardom%20of%20Russia">Muscovy</a> began to include <a href="North%20Asia">North Asia</a>. Throughout the Middle Ages and into the 18th century, the traditional division of the landmass of <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a> into two continents, Europe and Asia, followed Ptolemy, with the boundary following the <a href="Turkish%20Straits">Turkish Straits</a>, the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>, the <a href="Kerch%20Strait">Kerch Strait</a>, the <a href="Sea%20of%20Azov">Sea of Azov</a> and the <a href="Don%20River%20%28Russia%29">Don</a> (ancient <a href="Tanais">Tanais</a>). But maps produced during the 16th to 18th centuries tended to differ in how to continue the boundary beyond the Don bend at <a href="Kalach-na-Donu">Kalach-na-Donu</a> (where it is closest to the Volga, now joined with it by the <a href="Volga%E2%80%93Don%20Canal">Volga–Don Canal</a>), into territory not described in any detail by the ancient geographers. Around 1715, <a href="Herman%20Moll">Herman Moll</a> produced a map showing the northern part of the <a href="Ob%20River">Ob River</a> and the <a href="Irtysh%20River">Irtysh River</a>, a major tributary of the former, as components of a series of partly-joined waterways taking the boundary between Europe and Asia from the Turkish Straits, and the Don River all the way to the Arctic Ocean. In 1721, he produced a more up to date map that was easier to read. However, his idea to use major rivers almost exclusively as the line of demarcation was never taken up by other geographers.
Four years later, in 1725, <a href="Philip%20Johan%20von%20Strahlenberg">Philip Johan von Strahlenberg</a> was the first to depart from the classical Don boundary by proposing that mountain ranges could be included as boundaries between continents whenever there were deemed to be no suitable waterways, the Ob and Irtysh rivers notwithstanding. He drew a new line along the <a href="Volga%20River">Volga</a>, following the Volga north until the <a href="Samara%20Bend">Samara Bend</a>, along <a href="Obshchy%20Syrt">Obshchy Syrt</a> (the <a href="drainage%20divide">drainage divide</a> between Volga and <a href="Ural%20River">Ural</a>), and then north along <a href="Ural%20Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>. This was endorsed by the Russian Empire and introduced the convention that would eventually become commonly accepted, but not without criticism by many modern analytical geographers like <a href="Halford%20Mackinder">Halford Mackinder</a> who saw little validity in the Ural Mountains as a boundary between continents.
The mapmakers continued to differ on the boundary between the lower Don and Samara well into the 19th century. The published by the <a href="Russian%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Russian Academy of Sciences</a> has the boundary follow the Don beyond Kalach as far as <a href="Serafimovich%20%28town%29">Serafimovich</a> before cutting north towards <a href="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a>, while other 18th- to 19th-century mapmakers such as <a href="John%20Cary">John Cary</a> followed Strahlenberg's prescription. To the south, the <a href="Kuma%E2%80%93Manych%20Depression">Kuma–Manych Depression</a> was identified circa 1773 by a German naturalist, <a href="Peter%20Simon%20Pallas">Peter Simon Pallas</a>, as a valley that once connected the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, and subsequently was proposed as a natural boundary between continents.
By the mid-19th century, there were three main conventions, one following the Don, the <a href="Volga%E2%80%93Don%20Canal">Volga–Don Canal</a> and the Volga, the other following the Kuma–Manych Depression to the Caspian and then the Ural River, and the third abandoning the Don altogether, following the <a href="Greater%20Caucasus%20watershed">Greater Caucasus watershed</a> to the Caspian. The question was still treated as a "controversy" in geographical literature of the 1860s, with <a href="Douglas%20Freshfield">Douglas Freshfield</a> advocating the Caucasus crest boundary as the "best possible", citing support from various "modern geographers".
In <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, the boundary along the Kuma–Manych Depression was the most commonly used as early as 1906. In 1958, the Soviet Geographical Society formally recommended that the boundary between the Europe and Asia be drawn in textbooks from <a href="Baydaratskaya%20Bay">Baydaratskaya Bay</a>, on the <a href="Kara%20Sea">Kara Sea</a>, along the eastern foot of Ural Mountains, then following the <a href="Ural%20River">Ural River</a> until the <a href="Mugodzhar%20Hills">Mugodzhar Hills</a>, and then the <a href="Emba%20River">Emba River</a>; and Kuma–Manych Depression, thus placing the Caucasus entirely in Asia and the Urals entirely in Europe. However, most geographers in the Soviet Union favoured the boundary along the Caucasus crest, and this became the common convention in the later 20th century, although the Kuma–Manych boundary remained in use in some 20th-century maps.
Some view separation of <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a> into Asia and Europe as a residue of <a href="Eurocentrism">Eurocentrism</a>: "In physical, cultural and historical diversity, <a href="China">China</a> and <a href="India">India</a> are comparable to the entire European landmass, not to a single European country. [...]."
History.
Prehistory.
"<a href="Homo%20erectus%20georgicus">Homo erectus georgicus</a>", which lived roughly 1.8 million years ago in <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>, is the earliest <a href="Hominini">hominin</a> to have been discovered in Europe. <a href="Homo%20antecessor">Other</a> hominin remains, dating back roughly 1 million years, have been discovered in <a href="Archaeological%20Site%20of%20Atapuerca">Atapuerca</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. <a href="Neanderthal%20man">Neanderthal man</a> (named after the <a href="Neandertal%20%28valley%29">Neandertal valley</a> in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>) appeared in Europe 150,000 years ago (115,000 years ago it is found already in the territory of present-day <a href="Poland">Poland</a>) and disappeared from the fossil record about 28,000 years ago, with their final refuge being present-day <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>. The Neanderthals were supplanted by modern humans (<a href="Cro-Magnons">Cro-Magnons</a>), who appeared in Europe around 43,000 to 40,000 years ago. The earliest sites in Europe dated 48,000 years ago are <a href="Riparo%20Mochi">Riparo Mochi</a> (Italy), <a href="Geissenkl%C3%B6sterle">Geissenklösterle</a> (Germany) and <a href="Isturitz">Isturitz</a> (France).
The <a href="European%20Neolithic">European Neolithic</a> period—marked by the cultivation of crops and the raising of livestock, increased numbers of settlements and the widespread use of pottery—began around 7000 BCE in <a href="Greece">Greece</a> and the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a>, probably influenced by earlier farming practices in <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> and the <a href="Near%20East">Near East</a>. It spread from the Balkans along the valleys of the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> and the <a href="Rhine">Rhine</a> (<a href="Linear%20Pottery%20culture">Linear Pottery culture</a>), and along the <a href="Mediterranean%20coast">Mediterranean coast</a> (<a href="Cardial%20Ware">Cardial culture</a>). Between 4500 and 3000 BCE, these central European neolithic cultures developed further to the west and the north, transmitting newly acquired skills in producing copper artifacts. In Western Europe the Neolithic period was characterised not by large agricultural settlements but by field monuments, such as <a href="causewayed%20enclosure">causewayed enclosure</a>s, <a href="burial%20mound">burial mound</a>s and <a href="megalithic%20tomb">megalithic tomb</a>s. The <a href="Corded%20Ware">Corded Ware</a> cultural horizon flourished at the transition from the Neolithic to the <a href="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a>. During this period giant <a href="megalithic">megalithic</a> monuments, such as the <a href="Megalithic%20Temples%20of%20Malta">Megalithic Temples of Malta</a> and <a href="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, were constructed throughout Western and Southern Europe.
The <a href="European%20Bronze%20Age">European Bronze Age</a> began c. 3200 BCE in Greece with the <a href="Minoan%20civilization">Minoan civilisation</a> on <a href="Crete">Crete</a>, the first advanced civilisation in Europe. The Minoans were followed by the <a href="Mycenean%20Greece">Myceneans</a>, who collapsed suddenly around 1200 BCE, ushering the <a href="European%20Iron%20Age">European Iron Age</a>. Iron Age colonisation by the <a href="Greeks">Greeks</a> and <a href="Phoenicians">Phoenicians</a> gave rise to early <a href="Mediterranean%20basin">Mediterranean</a> cities. Early <a href="Iron%20Age%20Italy">Iron Age Italy</a> and <a href="Archaic%20Greece">Greece</a> from around the 8th century BCE gradually gave rise to historical Classical antiquity, whose beginning is sometimes dated to 776 BCE, the year of the first <a href="ancient%20Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>.
Classical antiquity.
Ancient Greece was the founding culture of Western civilisation. Western <a href="democracy">democratic</a> and <a href="rationalism">rationalist culture</a> are often attributed to Ancient Greece. The Greek city-state, the <a href="polis">polis</a>, was the fundamental political unit of classical Greece. In 508 BCE, <a href="Cleisthenes">Cleisthenes</a> instituted the world's first <a href="Athenian%20democracy">democratic</a> system of government in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>. The Greek political ideals were rediscovered in the late 18th century by European philosophers and idealists. Greece also generated many cultural contributions: in <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="humanism">humanism</a> and <a href="rationalism">rationalism</a> under <a href="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, <a href="Socrates">Socrates</a> and <a href="Plato">Plato</a>; in <a href="historiography">history</a> with <a href="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> and <a href="Thucydides">Thucydides</a>; in dramatic and narrative verse, starting with the epic poems of <a href="Homer">Homer</a>; in drama with <a href="Sophocles">Sophocles</a> and <a href="Euripides">Euripides</a>, in medicine with <a href="Hippocrates">Hippocrates</a> and <a href="Galen">Galen</a>; and in science with <a href="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a>, <a href="Euclid">Euclid</a> and <a href="Archimedes">Archimedes</a>. In the course of the 5th century BCE, several of the Greek <a href="city%20states">city states</a> would ultimately check the <a href="Achaemenid%20Empire">Achaemenid Persian</a> advance in Europe through the <a href="Greco-Persian%20Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a>, considered a pivotal moment in world history, as the 50 years of peace that followed are known as <a href="Fifth-century%20Athens">Golden Age of Athens</a>, the seminal period of ancient Greece that laid many of the foundations of Western civilisation. 
Greece was followed by <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Rome</a>, which left its mark on <a href="Roman%20law">law</a>, <a href="politics">politics</a>, <a href="Latin">language</a>, <a href="Roman%20engineering">engineering</a>, <a href="Roman%20architecture">architecture</a>, <a href="Centralized%20government">government</a> and many more key aspects in western civilisation. By 200 BCE, Rome had conquered <a href="Roman%20Italy">Italy</a> and over the following two centuries it conquered <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Greece</a> and <a href="Hispania">Hispania</a> (<a href="Spain">Spain</a> and <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>), the <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>n coast, much of the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, <a href="Gaul">Gaul</a> (<a href="France">France</a> and <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>) and <a href="Roman%20Britain">Britannia</a> (<a href="England">England</a> and <a href="Wales">Wales</a>).
Expanding from their base in central Italy beginning in the third century BCE, the Romans gradually expanded to eventually rule the entire Mediterranean Basin and Western Europe by the turn of the millennium. The <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a> ended in 27 BCE, when <a href="Augustus">Augustus</a> proclaimed the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a>. The two centuries that followed are known as the "<a href="pax%20romana">pax romana</a>", a period of unprecedented peace, prosperity and political stability in most of Europe. The empire continued to expand under emperors such as <a href="Antoninus%20Pius">Antoninus Pius</a> and <a href="Marcus%20Aurelius">Marcus Aurelius</a>, who spent time on the Empire's northern border fighting <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic</a>, <a href="Picts">Pictish</a> and <a href="Scottish%20people">Scottish</a> tribes. <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> was <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great%20and%20Christianity">legalised</a> by <a href="Constantine%20I">Constantine I</a> in 313 CE after three centuries of <a href="Persecution%20of%20early%20Christians%20in%20the%20Roman%20Empire">imperial persecution</a>. Constantine also permanently moved the capital of the empire from Rome to the city of <a href="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> (modern-day <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>) which was renamed <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> in his honour in 330 CE. Christianity became the sole official religion of the empire in 380 CE and in 391–392 CE, the emperor <a href="Theodosius%20I">Theodosius</a> outlawed pagan religions. This is sometimes considered to mark the end of antiquity; alternatively antiquity is considered to end with the <a href="fall%20of%20the%20Western%20Roman%20Empire">fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> in 476 CE; the closure of the pagan <a href="Platonic%20Academy">Platonic Academy of Athens</a> in 529 CE; or the rise of Islam in the early 7th century CE.
Early Middle Ages.
During the <a href="decline%20of%20the%20Roman%20Empire">decline of the Roman Empire</a>, Europe entered a long period of change arising from what historians call the "<a href="Age%20of%20Migrations">Age of Migrations</a>". There were numerous invasions and migrations amongst the <a href="Ostrogoths">Ostrogoths</a>, <a href="Visigoths">Visigoths</a>, <a href="Goths">Goths</a>, <a href="Vandals">Vandals</a>, <a href="Huns">Huns</a>, <a href="Franks">Franks</a>, <a href="Angles">Angles</a>, <a href="Saxons">Saxons</a>, <a href="Slavs">Slavs</a>, <a href="Pannonian%20Avars">Avars</a>, <a href="Bulgars">Bulgars</a> and, later on, the <a href="Vikings">Vikings</a>, <a href="Pechenegs">Pechenegs</a>, <a href="Cumans">Cumans</a> and <a href="Magyars">Magyars</a>. <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> thinkers such as <a href="Petrarch">Petrarch</a> would later refer to this as the "Dark Ages".
Isolated monastic communities were the only places to safeguard and compile written knowledge accumulated previously; apart from this very few written records survive and much literature, philosophy, mathematics and other thinking from the classical period disappeared from Western Europe, though they were preserved in the east, in the Byzantine Empire.
While the Roman empire in the west continued to decline, Roman traditions and the Roman state remained strong in the predominantly Greek-speaking <a href="Eastern%20Roman%20Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>, also known as the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>. During most of its existence, the Byzantine Empire was the most powerful economic, cultural and military force in Europe. Emperor <a href="Justinian%20I">Justinian I</a> presided over Constantinople's first golden age: he established a <a href="Code%20of%20Justinian">legal code</a> that forms the basis of many modern legal systems, funded the construction of the <a href="Hagia%20Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> and brought the Christian church under state control.
From the 7th century onwards, as the Byzantines and neighbouring <a href="Sasanids">Sasanid Persians</a> were severely weakened due to the protracted, centuries-lasting and frequent <a href="Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian%20wars">Byzantine–Sasanian wars</a>, the Muslim Arabs began to make inroads into historically Roman territory, taking the Levant and North Africa and making inroads into <a href="Asia%20Minor">Asia Minor</a>. In the mid-7th century, following the <a href="Muslim%20conquest%20of%20Persia">Muslim conquest of Persia</a>, Islam penetrated into the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> region. Over the next centuries Muslim forces took <a href="Cyprus%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">Cyprus</a>, <a href="Malta">Malta</a>, <a href="Emirate%20of%20Crete">Crete</a>, <a href="Emirate%20of%20Sicily">Sicily</a> and <a href="history%20of%20Islam%20in%20southern%20Italy">parts of southern Italy</a>. Between 711 and 720, most of the lands of the <a href="Visigothic%20Kingdom">Visigothic Kingdom</a> of <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberia</a> was brought under <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> rule—save for small areas in the north-west (<a href="Asturias">Asturias</a>) and largely <a href="Basque%20people">Basque</a> regions in the <a href="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>. This territory, under the Arabic name <a href="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a>, became part of the expanding <a href="Umayyad%20Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>. The unsuccessful <a href="Siege%20of%20Constantinople%20%28717%E2%80%93718%29">second siege of Constantinople</a> (717) weakened the <a href="Umayyad">Umayyad dynasty</a> and reduced their prestige. The Umayyads were then defeated by the <a href="Francia">Frankish</a> leader <a href="Charles%20Martel">Charles Martel</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tours">Battle of Poitiers</a> in 732, which ended their northward advance. In the remote regions of north-western Iberia and the middle <a href="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> the power of the Muslims in the south was scarcely felt. It was here that the foundations of the Christian kingdoms of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Asturias">Asturias</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Leon">Leon</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Galicia">Galicia</a> were laid and from where the reconquest of the Iberian Peninsula would start. However, no coordinated attempt would be made to drive the <a href="Moors">Moors</a> out. The Christian kingdoms were mainly focussed on their own internal power struggles. As a result, the <a href="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> took the greater part of eight hundred years, in which period a long list of Alfonsos, Sanchos, Ordoños, Ramiros, Fernandos and Bermudos would be fighting their Christian rivals as much as the Muslim invaders.
During the Dark Ages, the <a href="Western%20Roman%20Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> fell under the control of various tribes. The Germanic and Slav tribes established their domains over Western and Eastern Europe, respectively. Eventually the Frankish tribes were united under <a href="Clovis%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BI">Clovis I</a>. <a href="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>, a Frankish king of the <a href="Carolingian">Carolingian</a> dynasty who had conquered most of Western Europe, was anointed "<a href="Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>" by the Pope in 800. This led in 962 to the founding of the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>, which eventually became centred in the German principalities of central Europe.
<a href="East%20Central%20Europe">East Central Europe</a> saw the creation of the first Slavic states and the adoption of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> (. The powerful <a href="West%20Slavs">West Slavic</a> state of <a href="Great%20Moravia">Great Moravia</a> spread its territory all the way south to the Balkans, reaching its largest territorial extent under <a href="Svatopluk%20I%20of%20Moravia">Svatopluk I</a> and causing a series of armed conflicts with <a href="East%20Francia">East Francia</a>. Further south, the first <a href="South%20Slavs">South Slavic states</a> emerged in the late 7th and 8th century and adopted <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>: the <a href="First%20Bulgarian%20Empire">First Bulgarian Empire</a>, the <a href="Principality%20of%20Serbia%20%28early%20medieval%29">Serbian Principality</a> (later <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbia%20%28medieval%29">Kingdom</a> and <a href="Serbian%20Empire">Empire</a>) and the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Croatia">Duchy of Croatia</a> (later <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia%20%28925%E2%80%931102%29">Kingdom of Croatia</a>). To the East, the <a href="Kievan%20Rus">Kievan Rus</a> expanded from its capital in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> to become the largest state in Europe by the 10th century. In 988, <a href="Vladimir%20the%20Great">Vladimir the Great</a> adopted <a href="Russian%20Orthodox%20Church">Orthodox Christianity</a> as the religion of state. Further East, <a href="Volga%20Bulgaria">Volga Bulgaria</a> became an Islamic state in the 10th century, but was eventually absorbed into Russia several centuries later.
High and Late Middle Ages.
The period between the year 1000 and 1250 is known as the <a href="High%20Middle%20Ages">High Middle Ages</a>, followed by the <a href="Late%20Middle%20Ages">Late Middle Ages</a> until c. 1500.
During the High Middle Ages the population of Europe experienced significant growth, culminating in the <a href="Renaissance%20of%20the%2012th%20century">Renaissance of the 12th century</a>. Economic growth, together with the lack of safety on the mainland trading routes, made possible the development of major commercial routes along the coast of the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean</a> and <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>s. The growing wealth and independence acquired by some coastal cities gave the <a href="Maritime%20Republics">Maritime Republics</a> a leading role in the European scene.
The Middle Ages on the mainland were dominated by the two upper echelons of the social structure: the nobility and the clergy. <a href="Feudalism">Feudalism</a> developed in <a href="France">France</a> in the Early Middle Ages, and soon spread throughout Europe. A struggle for influence between the <a href="nobility">nobility</a> and the <a href="monarchy">monarchy</a> in England led to the writing of the "<a href="Magna%20Carta">Magna Carta</a>" and the establishment of a <a href="parliament">parliament</a>. The primary source of culture in this period came from the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. Through monasteries and cathedral schools, the Church was responsible for education in much of Europe.
The <a href="Papacy">Papacy</a> reached the height of its power during the High Middle Ages. An <a href="East-West%20Schism">East-West Schism</a> in 1054 split the former Roman Empire religiously, with the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> in the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> and the Roman Catholic Church in the former Western Roman Empire. In 1095 <a href="Pope%20Urban%20II">Pope Urban II</a> called for a <a href="Crusades">crusade</a> against <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> occupying <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> and the <a href="Holy%20Land">Holy Land</a>. In Europe itself, the Church organised the <a href="Inquisition">Inquisition</a> against heretics. In the <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, the <a href="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> concluded with the <a href="Granada%20War%23Last%20stand%20at%20Granada">fall of Granada in 1492</a>, ending over seven centuries of Islamic rule in the south-western peninsula.
In the east, a resurgent Byzantine Empire recaptured Crete and Cyprus from the Muslims, and reconquered the Balkans. Constantinople was the largest and wealthiest city in Europe from the 9th to the 12th centuries, with a population of approximately 400,000. The Empire was weakened following the defeat at <a href="Battle%20of%20Manzikert">Manzikert</a>, and was weakened considerably by the <a href="Siege%20of%20Constantinople%20%281204%29">sack of Constantinople in 1204</a>, during the <a href="Fourth%20Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a>. Although it would recover Constantinople in 1261, <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantium</a> <a href="Fall%20of%20Constantinople">fell in 1453</a> when <a href="Fall%20of%20Constantinople">Constantinople was taken</a> by the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.
In the 11th and 12th centuries, constant incursions by nomadic <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turkic</a> tribes, such as the <a href="Pechenegs">Pechenegs</a> and the <a href="Cuman-Kipchak%20Confederation">Cuman-Kipchaks</a>, caused a massive migration of <a href="Slavic%20peoples">Slavic</a> populations to the safer, heavily forested regions of the north, and temporarily halted the expansion of the Rus' state to the south and east. Like many other parts of <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>, these territories were <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Rus">overrun by the Mongols</a>. The invaders, who became known as <a href="Tatars">Tatars</a>, were mostly Turkic-speaking peoples under Mongol suzerainty. They established the state of the <a href="Golden%20Horde">Golden Horde</a> with headquarters in Crimea, which later adopted Islam as a religion, and ruled over modern-day southern and central Russia for more than three centuries. After the collapse of Mongol dominions, the first Romanian states (principalities) emerged in the 14th century: <a href="Moldavia">Moldavia</a> and <a href="Walachia">Walachia</a>. Previously, these territories were under the successive control of Pechenegs and Cumans. From the 12th to the 15th centuries, the <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> grew from a small principality under Mongol rule to the largest state in Europe, overthrowing the Mongols in 1480, and eventually becoming the <a href="Tsardom%20of%20Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>. The state was consolidated under <a href="Ivan%20III%20the%20Great">Ivan III the Great</a> and <a href="Ivan%20the%20Terrible">Ivan the Terrible</a>, steadily expanding to the east and south over the next centuries.
The <a href="Great%20Famine%20of%201315%E2%80%931317">Great Famine of 1315–1317</a> was the first <a href="Crisis%20of%20the%20Late%20Middle%20Ages">crisis</a> that would strike Europe in the late Middle Ages. The period between 1348 and 1420 witnessed the heaviest loss. The population of <a href="France%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">France</a> was reduced by half. Medieval Britain was afflicted by 95 famines, and France suffered the effects of 75 or more in the same period. Europe was devastated in the mid-14th century by the <a href="Black%20Death">Black Death</a>, one of the most deadly <a href="pandemic">pandemic</a>s in human history which killed an estimated 25 million people in Europe alone—a third of the <a href="Medieval%20demography">European population</a> at the time.
The plague had a devastating effect on Europe's social structure; it induced people to live for the moment as illustrated by <a href="Giovanni%20Boccaccio">Giovanni Boccaccio</a> in "<a href="The%20Decameron">The Decameron</a>" (1353). It was a serious blow to the Roman Catholic Church and led to increased <a href="persecution%20of%20Jews">persecution of Jews</a>, <a href="beggars">beggars</a> and <a href="leper">leper</a>s. The plague is thought to have returned every generation with varying <a href="virulence">virulence</a> and mortalities until the 18th century. During this period, more than 100 plague <a href="List%20of%20epidemics">epidemics</a> swept across Europe.
Early modern period.
The Renaissance was a period of cultural change originating in <a href="Florence">Florence</a>, and later spreading to the rest of Europe. The rise of a <a href="Renaissance%20humanism">new humanism</a> was accompanied by the recovery of forgotten <a href="Classical%20Greece">classical Greek</a> and Arabic knowledge from <a href="Monasticism">monastic</a> libraries, often translated from Arabic into <a href="Latin%20language">Latin</a>. The Renaissance spread across Europe between the 14th and 16th centuries: it saw the flowering of <a href="Renaissance%20art">art</a>, <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="music">music</a> and the <a href="History%20of%20science%20in%20the%20Renaissance">sciences</a>, under the joint patronage of <a href="Royal%20family">royalty</a>, the nobility, the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> and an emerging merchant class. Patrons in Italy, including the <a href="Medici">Medici</a> family of Florentine bankers and the <a href="Pope">Pope</a>s in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, funded prolific <a href="quattrocento">quattrocento</a> and <a href="cinquecento">cinquecento</a> artists such as <a href="Raphael">Raphael</a>, <a href="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a> and <a href="Leonardo%20da%20Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>.
Political intrigue within the Church in the mid-14th century caused the <a href="Western%20Schism">Western Schism</a>. During this forty-year period, two popes—one in <a href="Avignon">Avignon</a> and one in Rome—claimed rulership over the Church. Although the schism was eventually healed in 1417, the papacy's spiritual authority had suffered greatly. In the 15th century, Europe started to extend itself beyond its geographic frontiers. Spain and Portugal, the greatest naval powers of the time, took the lead in exploring the world. Exploration reached the <a href="Southern%20Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> in the Atlantic and the Southern tip of Africa. <a href="Christopher%20Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> reached the <a href="New%20World">New World</a> in 1492, and <a href="Vasco%20da%20Gama">Vasco da Gama</a> opened the ocean route to the <a href="Orient">East</a> linking the Atlantic and <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>s in 1498. The Portuguese-born explorer <a href="Ferdinand%20Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> reached Asia westward across the Atlantic and the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>s in a Spanish expedition, resulting in the first <a href="Timeline%20of%20Magellan%27s%20circumnavigation">circumnavigation of the globe</a>, completed by the Spaniard <a href="Juan%20Sebasti%C3%A1n%20Elcano">Juan Sebastián Elcano</a> (1519–1522). Soon after, the Spanish and Portuguese began establishing large global empires in the <a href="Americas">Americas</a>, Asia, Africa and Oceania. France, the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and England soon followed in building large colonial empires with vast holdings in Africa, the Americas and Asia. In 1588, a <a href="Spanish%20armada">Spanish armada</a> failed to invade England. A year later <a href="English%20Armada">England tried unsuccessfully to invade Spain</a>, allowing <a href="Philip%20II%20of%20Spain">Philip II of Spain</a> to maintain his dominant war capacity in Europe. This English disaster also allowed the Spanish fleet to retain its capability to wage war for the next decades. However, two more Spanish armadas failed to invade England (<a href="2nd%20Spanish%20Armada">2nd Spanish Armada</a> and <a href="3rd%20Spanish%20Armada">3rd Spanish Armada</a>).
The Church's power was further weakened by the <a href="Protestant%20reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> in 1517 when German theologian <a href="Martin%20Luther">Martin Luther</a> nailed his "<a href="Ninety-five%20Theses">Ninety-five Theses</a>" criticising the selling of indulgences to the church door. He was subsequently excommunicated in the papal bull "<a href="Exsurge%20Domine">Exsurge Domine</a>" in 1520 and his followers were condemned in the 1521 <a href="Diet%20of%20Worms">Diet of Worms</a>, which divided German princes between <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> and Roman Catholic faiths. <a href="European%20wars%20of%20religion">Religious fighting and warfare</a> spread with Protestantism. The plunder of the empires of the Americas allowed Spain to finance <a href="Spanish%20Inquisition">religious persecution</a> in Europe for over a century. The <a href="Thirty%20Years%20War">Thirty Years War</a> (1618–1648) crippled the Holy Roman Empire and devastated much of <a href="Early%20Modern%20history%20of%20Germany">Germany</a>, killing between 25 and 40 percent of its population. In the aftermath of the <a href="Peace%20of%20Westphalia">Peace of Westphalia</a>, France rose to predominance within Europe.
The 17th century in central and parts of eastern Europe was a period of general <a href="The%20General%20Crisis">decline</a>; the region experienced more than 150 famines in a 200-year period between 1501 and 1700. From the <a href="Union%20of%20Krewo">Union of Krewo</a> (1385) east-central Europe was dominated by the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Poland%20%281385%E2%80%931569%29">Kingdom of Poland</a> and the <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a>. The <a href="hegemony">hegemony</a> of the vast <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> had ended with the devastation brought by the <a href="Second%20Northern%20War">Second Northern War</a> (<a href="Swedish%20Deluge">Deluge</a>) and subsequent conflicts; the state itself was <a href="Partitions%20of%20Poland">partitioned</a> and ceased to exist at the end of the 18th century.
From the 15th to 18th centuries, when the disintegrating khanates of the <a href="Golden%20Horde">Golden Horde</a> were conquered by Russia, <a href="Crimean%20Tatars">Tatars</a> from the <a href="Crimean%20Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a> frequently <a href="Crimean-Nogai%20raids%20into%20East%20Slavic%20lands">raided</a> Eastern Slavic lands to <a href="Slavery%20in%20the%20Ottoman%20Empire">capture slaves</a>. Further east, the <a href="Nogai%20Horde">Nogai Horde</a> and <a href="Kazakh%20Khanate">Kazakh Khanate</a> frequently raided the Slavic-speaking areas of contemporary Russia and Ukraine for hundreds of years, until the Russian expansion and conquest of most of northern Eurasia (i.e. Eastern Europe, Central Asia and Siberia).
The Renaissance and the <a href="New%20Monarchs">New Monarchs</a> marked the start of an Age of Discovery, a period of exploration, invention and scientific development. Among the great figures of the Western <a href="scientific%20revolution">scientific revolution</a> of the 16th and 17th centuries were <a href="Copernicus">Copernicus</a>, <a href="Kepler">Kepler</a>, <a href="Galileo">Galileo</a> and <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a>. According to Peter Barrett, "It is widely accepted that 'modern science' arose in the Europe of the 17th century (towards the end of the Renaissance), introducing a new understanding of the natural world."
18th and 19th centuries.
The Age of Enlightenment was a powerful intellectual movement during the 18th century promoting scientific and reason-based thoughts. Discontent with the aristocracy and clergy's monopoly on political power in France resulted in the French Revolution, and the establishment of the <a href="French%20First%20Republic">First Republic</a> as a result of which the monarchy and many of the nobility perished during the initial <a href="Reign%20of%20Terror">reign of terror</a>. <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> rose to power in the aftermath of the French Revolution, and established the <a href="First%20French%20Empire">First French Empire</a> that, during the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, grew to encompass large parts of Europe before collapsing in 1815 with the <a href="Battle%20of%20Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a>. <a href="Napoleonic%20Empire">Napoleonic rule</a> resulted in the further dissemination of the ideals of the French Revolution, including that of the <a href="nation%20state">nation state</a>, as well as the widespread adoption of the French models of <a href="centralised%20government">administration</a>, <a href="Napoleonic%20code">law</a> and <a href="Education%20in%20France">education</a>. The <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, convened after Napoleon's downfall, established a new <a href="balance%20of%20power%20%28international%20relations%29">balance of power</a> in Europe centred on the five "<a href="Great%20Power">Great Power</a>s": the UK, France, <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>, <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austria</a> and Russia. This balance would remain in place until the <a href="Revolutions%20of%201848">Revolutions of 1848</a>, during which liberal uprisings affected all of Europe except for Russia and the UK. These revolutions were eventually put down by conservative elements and few reforms resulted. The year 1859 saw the unification of Romania, as a nation state, from smaller principalities. In 1867, the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20empire">Austro-Hungarian empire</a> was <a href="Ausgleich">formed</a>; 1871 saw the unifications of both <a href="Italian%20unification">Italy</a> and <a href="Unification%20of%20Germany">Germany</a> as nation-states from smaller principalities.
In parallel, the <a href="Eastern%20Question">Eastern Question</a> grew more complex ever since the Ottoman defeat in the <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281768%E2%80%931774%29">Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)</a>. As the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire seemed imminent, the <a href="Great%20Power">Great Power</a>s struggled to safeguard their strategic and commercial interests in the Ottoman domains. The <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a> stood to benefit from the decline, whereas the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Empire</a> and <a href="United%20Kingdom">Britain</a> perceived the preservation of the Ottoman Empire to be in their best interests. Meanwhile, the <a href="Serbian%20revolution">Serbian revolution</a> (1804) and <a href="Greek%20War%20of%20Independence">Greek War of Independence</a> (1821) marked the beginning of the end of Ottoman rule in the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a>, which ended with the <a href="Balkan%20Wars">Balkan Wars</a> in 1912–1913. Formal recognition of the "de facto" independent principalities of <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, <a href="Principality%20of%20Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="Romania">Romania</a> ensued at the <a href="Congress%20of%20Berlin">Congress of Berlin</a> in 1878.
The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> in the last part of the 18th century and spread throughout Europe. The invention and implementation of new technologies resulted in rapid urban growth, mass employment and the rise of a new working class. Reforms in social and economic spheres followed, including the <a href="Factory%20Acts">first laws</a> on <a href="child%20labour">child labour</a>, the legalisation of <a href="trade%20union">trade union</a>s, and the <a href="abolitionism%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">abolition of slavery</a>. In Britain, the <a href="Public%20Health%20Act%20of%201875">Public Health Act of 1875</a> was passed, which significantly improved living conditions in many British cities. Europe's population increased from about 100 million in 1700 to 400 million by 1900. The last major famine recorded in Western Europe, the <a href="Great%20Famine%20%28Ireland%29">Great Famine of Ireland</a>, caused death and mass emigration of millions of Irish people. In the 19th century, 70 million people left Europe in migrations to various European colonies abroad and to the United States. Demographic growth meant that, by 1900, Europe's share of the world's population was 25%.
20th century to the present.
Two world wars and an economic depression dominated the first half of the 20th century. World War I was fought between 1914 and 1918. It started when <a href="Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand%20of%20Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria</a> was assassinated by the <a href="Yugoslav%20nationalism">Yugoslav nationalist</a> <a href="Gavrilo%20Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>. Most European nations were drawn into the war, which was fought between the <a href="Entente%20Powers">Entente Powers</a> (<a href="French%20Third%20Republic">France</a>, <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>, Portugal, <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russia</a>, the United Kingdom, and later <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="Romania">Romania</a> and the United States) and the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a> (<a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, <a href="German%20Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> and the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>). The war left more than 16 million civilians and military dead. Over 60 million European soldiers were mobilised from 1914 to 1918.
Russia was plunged into the <a href="Russian%20Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, which threw down the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Tsarist monarchy</a> and replaced it with the <a href="communist">communist</a> <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, leading also to the independence of many former <a href="Governorate%20%28Russia%29">Russian governorates</a>, such as <a href="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="Latvia">Latvia</a> and <a href="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, as new European countries. <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> and the Ottoman Empire collapsed and broke up into separate nations, and many other nations had their borders redrawn. The <a href="Treaty%20of%20Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>, which officially ended World War I in 1919, was harsh towards Germany, upon whom it placed full responsibility for the war and imposed heavy sanctions. Excess deaths in Russia over the course of World War I and the <a href="Russian%20Civil%20War">Russian Civil War</a> (including the postwar <a href="Russian%20famine%20of%201921">famine</a>) amounted to a combined total of 18 million. In 1932–1933, under <a href="Stalin">Stalin</a>'s leadership, confiscations of grain by the Soviet authorities contributed to the <a href="Soviet%20famine%20of%201932-1933">second Soviet famine</a> which caused millions of deaths; surviving <a href="kulak">kulak</a>s were persecuted and many sent to <a href="Gulag">Gulag</a>s to do <a href="Unfree%20labour">forced labour</a>. Stalin was also responsible for the <a href="Great%20Purge">Great Purge</a> of 1937–38 in which the <a href="NKVD">NKVD</a> executed 681,692 people; millions of people were <a href="population%20transfer%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">deported and exiled</a> to remote areas of the Soviet Union.
The <a href="social%20revolution">social revolution</a>s sweeping through Russia also affected other European nations following <a href="The%20Great%20War">The Great War</a>: in 1919, with the <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a> in Germany and the <a href="First%20Austrian%20Republic">First Austrian Republic</a>; in 1922, with <a href="Benito%20Mussolini">Mussolini</a>'s one-party <a href="Fascism">fascist</a> government in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> and in <a href="Atat%C3%BCrk">Atatürk</a>'s <a href="Turkey">Turkish Republic</a>, adopting the Western alphabet and state <a href="secularism">secularism</a>.
Economic instability, caused in part by debts incurred in the First World War and 'loans' to Germany played havoc in Europe in the late 1920s and 1930s. This, and the <a href="Wall%20Street%20Crash%20of%201929">Wall Street Crash of 1929</a>, brought about the worldwide <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>. Helped by the economic crisis, social instability and the threat of communism, <a href="Fascism">fascist movements</a> developed throughout Europe placing <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> in power of what became <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.
In 1933, Hitler became the leader of Germany and began to work towards his goal of building Greater Germany. Germany re-expanded and took back the <a href="Saarland">Saarland</a> and <a href="Rhineland">Rhineland</a> in 1935 and 1936. In 1938, <a href="Austria">Austria</a> became a part of Germany following the <a href="Anschluss">Anschluss</a>. Later that year, following the <a href="Munich%20Agreement">Munich Agreement</a> signed by Germany, France, the United Kingdom and Italy, Germany annexed the <a href="Sudetenland">Sudetenland</a>, which was a part of <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> inhabited by ethnic Germans, and in early 1939, the remainder of Czechoslovakia was split into the <a href="Protectorate%20of%20Bohemia%20and%20Moravia">Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia</a>, controlled by Germany and the <a href="Slovak%20Republic%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">Slovak Republic</a>. At the time, Britain and France preferred a policy of <a href="appeasement">appeasement</a>.
With tensions mounting between Germany and <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">Poland</a> over the future of <a href="Gda%C5%84sk">Danzig</a>, the Germans turned to the Soviets and signed the <a href="Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop%20Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>, which allowed the Soviets to invade the Baltic states and parts of Poland and Romania. Germany <a href="Invasion%20of%20Poland">invaded Poland</a> on 1 September 1939, prompting France and the United Kingdom to declare war on Germany on 3 September, opening the <a href="European%20Theatre%20of%20World%20War%20II">European Theatre of World War II</a>. The <a href="Soviet%20invasion%20of%20Poland">Soviet invasion of Poland</a> started on 17 September and Poland fell soon thereafter. On 24 September, the Soviet Union attacked the <a href="Soviet%20occupation%20of%20the%20Baltic%20states%20%281940%29">Baltic countries</a> and, on November 30, Finland, the latter of which was followed by the devastating <a href="Winter%20War">Winter War</a> for the Red Army. The British hoped to land at <a href="Battles%20of%20Narvik">Narvik</a> and send troops to aid Finland, but their primary objective in the landing was to encircle Germany and cut the Germans off from Scandinavian resources. Around the same time, Germany moved troops into Denmark. The <a href="Phoney%20War">Phoney War</a> continued.
In May 1940, Germany <a href="Battle%20of%20France">attacked France</a> through the Low Countries. France capitulated in June 1940. By August, Germany began a <a href="Battle%20of%20Britain">bombing offensive on Britain</a>, but failed to convince the Britons to give up. In 1941, Germany invaded the Soviet Union in <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>. On 7 December 1941 <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japan</a>'s <a href="attack%20on%20Pearl%20Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> drew the United States into the conflict as allies of the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>, and other <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">allied</a> forces. 
After the staggering <a href="Battle%20of%20Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a> in 1943, the German offensive in the Soviet Union turned into a continual fallback. The <a href="Battle%20of%20Kursk">Battle of Kursk</a>, which involved the largest <a href="Battle%20of%20Prokhorovka">tank battle</a> in history, was the last major German offensive on the <a href="Eastern%20Front%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Eastern Front</a>. In June 1944, British and American forces invaded France in the <a href="Normandy%20landings">D-Day landings</a>, opening a new front against Germany. Berlin finally <a href="Battle%20of%20Berlin">fell in 1945</a>, ending World War II in Europe. The war was the largest and most destructive in human history, with <a href="World%20War%20II%20casualties">60 million dead across the world</a>. More than 40 million people in Europe had died as a result of World War II, including between 11 and 17 million people who perished during <a href="the%20Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>. The Soviet Union <a href="World%20War%20II%20casualties%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">lost around 27 million people</a> (mostly civilians) during the war, about half of all World War II casualties. By the end of World War II, Europe had more than 40 million <a href="refugee">refugee</a>s. Several <a href="World%20War%20II%20evacuation%20and%20expulsion">post-war expulsions</a> in Central and Eastern Europe displaced a total of about 20 million people, in particular, <a href="Flight%20and%20expulsion%20of%20Germans%20%281944%E2%80%931950%29">German-speakers from all over Eastern Europe</a>.
World War I, and especially World War II, diminished the eminence of Western Europe in world affairs. After World War II the map of Europe was redrawn at the <a href="Yalta%20Conference">Yalta Conference</a> and divided into two blocs, the Western countries and the communist Eastern bloc, separated by what was later called by <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> an "<a href="Iron%20Curtain">Iron Curtain</a>". The United States and Western Europe established the <a href="NATO">NATO</a> alliance and, later, the Soviet Union and Central Europe established the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>. Particular hot spots after the Second World War were <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> and <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a>, whereby the <a href="Free%20Territory%20of%20Trieste">Free Territory of Trieste</a>, founded in 1947 with the UN, was dissolved in 1954 and 1975, respectively. The <a href="Berlin%20blockade">Berlin blockade</a> in 1948 and 1949 and the construction of the <a href="Berlin%20Wall">Berlin Wall</a> in 1961 were one of the great international crises of the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>.
The two new <a href="superpower">superpower</a>s, the United States and the Soviet Union, became locked in a fifty-year-long Cold War, centred on <a href="nuclear%20proliferation">nuclear proliferation</a>. At the same time <a href="decolonisation">decolonisation</a>, which had already started after World War I, gradually resulted in the independence of most of the European colonies in Asia and Africa.
In the 1980s the <a href="glasnost">reforms</a> of <a href="Mikhail%20Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> and the <a href="Solidarity%20%28Polish%20trade%20union%29">Solidarity</a> movement in Poland weakened the previously rigid communist system. The opening of the <a href="Iron%20Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> at the <a href="Pan-European%20Picnic">Pan-European Picnic</a> then set in motion a peaceful chain reaction, at the end of which the <a href="Eastern%20bloc">Eastern bloc</a>, the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> and <a href="communism">communism</a> collapsed, and the Cold War ended. Germany was reunited, after the symbolic <a href="Berlin%20Wall%23Fall%20of%20the%20Wall">fall of the Berlin Wall</a> in 1989 and the maps of Central and Eastern Europe were redrawn once more. This made old previously interrupted cultural and economic relationships possible, and previously isolated cities such as <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="Prague">Prague</a>, <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a> and <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> were now again in the centre of Europe.
<a href="European%20integration">European integration</a> also grew after World War II. In 1949 the <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a> was founded, following a speech by Sir <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, with the idea of unifying Europe to achieve common goals. It includes all European states except for <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="Vatican%20City">Vatican City</a>. The <a href="Treaty%20of%20Rome">Treaty of Rome</a> in 1957 established the <a href="European%20Economic%20Community">European Economic Community</a> between six Western European states with the goal of a unified economic policy and common market. In 1967 the EEC, <a href="European%20Coal%20and%20Steel%20Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>, and <a href="Euratom">Euratom</a> formed the <a href="European%20Community">European Community</a>, which in 1993 became the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. The EU established a <a href="European%20Parliament">parliament</a>, <a href="European%20Court%20of%20Justice">court</a> and <a href="European%20Central%20Bank">central bank</a>, and introduced the <a href="euro">euro</a> as a unified currency. Between 2004 and 2013, more Central and Eastern European countries began joining, <a href="Enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">expanding the EU</a> to 28 European countries and once more making Europe a major economical and political centre of power. However, the United Kingdom withdrew from the EU on 31 January 2020, as a result of a <a href="2016%20United%20Kingdom%20European%20Union%20membership%20referendum">June 2016 referendum on EU membership</a>.
Geography.
Europe makes up the western fifth of the <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>n landmass. It has a higher ratio of coast to landmass than any other continent or subcontinent. Its maritime borders consist of the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west and the Mediterranean, Black and Caspian Seas to the south.
Land relief in Europe shows great variation within relatively small areas. The southern regions are more mountainous, while moving north the terrain descends from the high <a href="Alps">Alps</a>, <a href="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> and <a href="Carpathians">Carpathians</a>, through hilly uplands, into broad, low northern plains, which are vast in the east. This extended lowland is known as the <a href="Great%20European%20Plain">Great European Plain</a> and at its heart lies the <a href="North%20German%20Plain">North German Plain</a>. An arc of uplands also exists along the north-western seaboard, which begins in the western parts of the islands of Britain and Ireland, and then continues along the mountainous, <a href="fjord">fjord</a>-cut spine of Norway.
This description is simplified. Sub-regions such as the <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> and the <a href="Italian%20Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a> contain their own complex features, as does mainland Central Europe itself, where the relief contains many plateaus, river valleys and basins that complicate the general trend. Sub-regions like <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>, Britain and Ireland are special cases. The former is a land unto itself in the northern ocean which is counted as part of Europe, while the latter are upland areas that were once joined to the mainland until <a href="sea%20level%20rise">rising sea levels</a> cut them off.
Climate.
Europe lies mainly in the <a href="temperate">temperate</a> climate zones, being subjected to <a href="prevailing%20westerlies">prevailing westerlies</a>. The climate is milder in comparison to other areas of the same latitude around the globe due to the influence of the <a href="Gulf%20Stream">Gulf Stream</a>. The Gulf Stream is nicknamed "Europe's central heating", because it makes Europe's climate warmer and wetter than it would otherwise be. The Gulf Stream not only carries warm water to Europe's coast but also warms up the prevailing westerly winds that blow across the continent from the Atlantic Ocean.

Geology.
The geological history of Europe traces back to the formation of the <a href="Baltic%20Shield">Baltic Shield</a> (Fennoscandia) and the <a href="Sarmatian%20craton">Sarmatian craton</a>, both around 2.25 billion years ago, followed by the <a href="Volgo%E2%80%93Uralia">Volgo–Uralia</a> shield, the three together leading to the <a href="East%20European%20craton">East European craton</a> (≈ <a href="Baltica">Baltica</a>) which became a part of the <a href="supercontinent">supercontinent</a> <a href="Columbia%20%28supercontinent%29">Columbia</a>. Around 1.1 billion years ago, Baltica and Arctica (as part of the <a href="Laurentia">Laurentia</a> block) became joined to <a href="Rodinia">Rodinia</a>, later resplitting around 550 million years ago to reform as Baltica. Around 440 million years ago <a href="Euramerica">Euramerica</a> was formed from Baltica and Laurentia; a further joining with <a href="Gondwana">Gondwana</a> then leading to the formation of <a href="Pangea">Pangea</a>. Around 190 million years ago, Gondwana and <a href="Laurasia">Laurasia</a> split apart due to the widening of the Atlantic Ocean. Finally and very soon afterwards, Laurasia itself split up again, into Laurentia (North America) and the Eurasian continent. The land connection between the two persisted for a considerable time, via <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>, leading to interchange of animal species. From around 50 million years ago, rising and falling sea levels have determined the actual shape of Europe and its connections with continents such as Asia. Europe's present shape dates to the <a href="late%20Tertiary">late Tertiary</a> period about five million years ago.
The geology of Europe is hugely varied and complex and gives rise to the wide variety of landscapes found across the continent, from the <a href="Scottish%20Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a> to the rolling <a href="plain">plain</a>s of Hungary. Europe's most significant feature is the dichotomy between highland and mountainous <a href="Southern%20Europe">Southern Europe</a> and a vast, partially underwater, northern plain ranging from Ireland in the west to the <a href="Ural%20Mountains">Ural Mountains</a> in the east. These two halves are separated by the mountain chains of the <a href="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> and <a href="Alps">Alps</a>/<a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathians</a>. The northern plains are delimited in the west by the <a href="Scandinavian%20Mountains">Scandinavian Mountains</a> and the mountainous parts of the British Isles. Major shallow water bodies submerging parts of the northern plains are the <a href="Celtic%20Sea">Celtic Sea</a>, the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a>, the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a> complex and <a href="Barents%20Sea">Barents Sea</a>.
The northern plain contains the old geological continent of <a href="Baltica">Baltica</a> and so may be regarded geologically as the "main continent", while peripheral highlands and mountainous regions in the south and west constitute fragments from various other geological continents. Most of the older geology of western Europe existed as part of the ancient <a href="microcontinent">microcontinent</a> <a href="Avalonia">Avalonia</a>.
Flora.
Having lived side by side with agricultural peoples for millennia, Europe's animals and plants have been profoundly affected by the presence and activities of man. With the exception of <a href="Fennoscandia">Fennoscandia</a> and northern Russia, few areas of untouched wilderness are currently found in Europe, except for various <a href="national%20park">national park</a>s.
The main natural vegetation cover in Europe is mixed <a href="forest">forest</a>. The conditions for growth are very favourable. In the north, the <a href="Gulf%20Stream">Gulf Stream</a> and <a href="North%20Atlantic%20Current">North Atlantic Drift</a> warm the continent. Southern Europe could be described as having a warm, but mild climate. There are frequent summer droughts in this region. Mountain ridges also affect the conditions. Some of these (<a href="Alps">Alps</a>, <a href="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>) are oriented east–west and allow the wind to carry large masses of water from the ocean in the interior. Others are oriented south–north (<a href="Scandinavian%20Mountains">Scandinavian Mountains</a>, <a href="Dinaric%20Alps">Dinarides</a>, <a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathians</a>, <a href="Apennine%20Mountains">Apennines</a>) and because the rain falls primarily on the side of mountains that is oriented towards the sea, forests grow well on this side, while on the other side, the conditions are much less favourable. Few corners of mainland Europe have not been grazed by <a href="livestock">livestock</a> at some point in time and the cutting down of the pre-agricultural forest habitat caused disruption to the original plant and animal ecosystems.
Possibly 80 to 90 percent of Europe was once covered by forest. It stretched from the Mediterranean Sea to the Arctic Ocean. Although over half of Europe's original forests disappeared through the centuries of <a href="deforestation">deforestation</a>, Europe still has over one quarter of its land area as forest, such as the <a href="Temperate%20broadleaf%20and%20mixed%20forest">broadleaf and mixed</a> forests, <a href="taiga">taiga</a> of Scandinavia and Russia, mixed <a href="rainforest">rainforest</a>s of the Caucasus and the <a href="Cork%20oak">Cork oak</a> forests in the western Mediterranean. During recent times, deforestation has been slowed and many trees have been planted. However, in many cases monoculture <a href="plantation">plantation</a>s of <a href="Pinophyta">conifers</a> have replaced the original mixed natural forest, because these grow quicker. The plantations now cover vast areas of land, but offer poorer habitats for many European forest dwelling species which require a mixture of tree species and diverse forest structure. The amount of natural forest in Western Europe is just 2–3% or less, while in its Western Russia its 5–10%. The <a href="European%20countries%20by%20forest%20area">European country with the smallest percentage of forested area</a> is <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> (1%), while the most forested country is Finland (77%).
In temperate Europe, mixed forest with both <a href="flowering%20plant">broadleaf</a> and coniferous trees dominate. The most important species in central and western Europe are <a href="beech">beech</a> and <a href="oak">oak</a>. In the north, the taiga is a mixed <a href="spruce">spruce</a>–<a href="pine">pine</a>–<a href="birch">birch</a> forest; further north within Russia and extreme northern Scandinavia, the taiga gives way to <a href="tundra">tundra</a> as the Arctic is approached. In the Mediterranean, many <a href="olive">olive</a> trees have been planted, which are very well adapted to its arid climate; <a href="Cupressus%20sempervirens">Mediterranean Cypress</a> is also widely planted in southern Europe. The semi-arid Mediterranean region hosts much scrub forest. A narrow east–west tongue of Eurasian <a href="grassland">grassland</a> (the <a href="steppe">steppe</a>) extends westwards from <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and southern Russia and ends in Hungary and traverses into taiga to the north.
Fauna.
Glaciation during the <a href="Quaternary%20glaciation">most recent ice age</a> and the presence of man affected the distribution of <a href="Fauna%20of%20Europe">European fauna</a>. As for the animals, in many parts of Europe most large animals and top <a href="predator">predator</a> species have been hunted to extinction. The <a href="woolly%20mammoth">woolly mammoth</a> was extinct before the end of the <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> period. Today <a href="wolf">wolves</a> (<a href="carnivore">carnivore</a>s) and <a href="bear">bear</a>s (<a href="omnivore">omnivore</a>s) are endangered. Once they were found in most parts of Europe. However, deforestation and hunting caused these animals to withdraw further and further. By the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> the bears' habitats were limited to more or less inaccessible mountains with sufficient forest cover. Today, the <a href="European%20brown%20bear">brown bear</a> lives primarily in the <a href="Balkan">Balkan peninsula</a>, Scandinavia and Russia; a small number also persist in other countries across Europe (Austria, Pyrenees etc.), but in these areas brown bear populations are fragmented and marginalised because of the destruction of their habitat. In addition, <a href="polar%20bear">polar bear</a>s may be found on <a href="Svalbard">Svalbard</a>, a Norwegian archipelago far north of Scandinavia. The <a href="Eurasian%20wolf">wolf</a>, the second largest predator in Europe after the brown bear, can be found primarily in <a href="Central%20and%20Eastern%20Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a> and in the Balkans, with a handful of packs in pockets of <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a> (Scandinavia, Spain, etc.).
