Important European herbivores are snails, larvae, fish, different birds and mammals, like rodents, deer and roe deer, boars and living in the mountains, marmots, steinbocks, chamois among others. A number of insects, such as the <a href="small%20tortoiseshell">small tortoiseshell</a> butterfly, add to the biodiversity.
The extinction of the <a href="Cretan%20Dwarf%20Hippopotamus">dwarf hippos</a> and <a href="dwarf%20elephant">dwarf elephant</a>s has been linked to the earliest arrival of humans on the islands of the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>.
Sea creatures are also an important part of European flora and fauna. The sea flora is mainly <a href="phytoplankton">phytoplankton</a>. Important animals that live in European seas are <a href="zooplankton">zooplankton</a>, <a href="mollusc">mollusc</a>s, <a href="echinoderm">echinoderm</a>s, different <a href="crustacean">crustacean</a>s, <a href="squid">squid</a>s and <a href="octopuses">octopuses</a>, fish, <a href="dolphin">dolphin</a>s and <a href="whales">whales</a>.
Biodiversity is protected in Europe through the Council of Europe's <a href="Convention%20on%20the%20Conservation%20of%20European%20Wildlife%20and%20Natural%20Habitats">Bern Convention</a>, which has also been signed by the <a href="European%20Community">European Community</a> as well as non-European states.
Politics.
The political map of Europe is substantially derived from the re-organisation of Europe following the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> in 1815. The prevalent form of government in Europe is <a href="parliamentary%20democracy">parliamentary democracy</a>, in most cases in the form of <a href="Republic">Republic</a>; in 1815, the prevalent form of government was still the <a href="Monarchies%20in%20Europe">Monarchy</a>. Europe's remaining eleven monarchies are <a href="constitutional%20monarchy">constitutional</a>.
<a href="European%20integration">European integration</a> is the process of political, legal, economic (and in some cases social and cultural) integration of European states as it has been pursued by the powers sponsoring the <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a> since the end of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>
The <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> has been the focus of economic integration on the continent since its foundation in 1993. More recently, the <a href="Eurasian%20Economic%20Union">Eurasian Economic Union</a> has been established as a counterpart comprising former Soviet states.
27 European states are members of the politico-economic European Union, 26 of the border-free <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a> and 19 of the monetary union <a href="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>. Among the smaller European organisations are the <a href="Nordic%20Council">Nordic Council</a>, the <a href="Benelux">Benelux</a>, the <a href="Baltic%20Assembly">Baltic Assembly</a> and the <a href="Visegr%C3%A1d%20Group">Visegrád Group</a>.

Economy.
As a continent, the economy of Europe is currently the largest on Earth and it is the richest region as measured by assets under management with over $32.7 trillion compared to North America's $27.1 trillion in 2008. In 2009 Europe remained the wealthiest region. Its $37.1 trillion in assets under management represented one-third of the world's wealth. It was one of several regions where wealth surpassed its precrisis year-end peak. As with other continents, Europe has a large variation of wealth among its countries. The richer states tend to be in the <a href="Western%20Europe">West</a>, followed by <a href="Central%20Europe">Central Europe</a>ans, while some of the <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a> economies are still emerging from the <a href="collapse%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">collapse of the Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>.
The model of the <a href="Blue%20Banana">Blue Banana</a> was designed as an economic geographic representation of the respective economic power of the regions, which was further developed into the <a href="Golden%20Banana">Golden Banana</a> or Blue Star. The trade between East and West, as well as towards Asia, which had been disrupted for a long time by the two world wars, new borders and the Cold War, increased sharply after 1989. In addition, there is new impetus from the Chinese <a href="Belt%20and%20Road%20Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a> across the <a href="Suez%20Canal">Suez Canal</a> towards Africa and Asia.
The European Union, a political entity composed of 27 European states, comprises the <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20GDP%20%28nominal%29">largest single economic area</a> in the world. Nineteen EU <a href="Eurozone">countries</a> share the <a href="euro">euro</a> as a common currency.
Five European countries rank in the top ten of the world's largest <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20GDP%20%28PPP%29">national economies in GDP (PPP)</a>. This includes (ranks according to the <a href="The%20World%20Factbook">CIA</a>): Germany (6), Russia (7), the United Kingdom (10), France (11) and Italy (13).
There is huge disparity between many European countries in terms of their income. The richest in terms of nominal GDP is <a href="Monaco">Monaco</a> with its US$185,829 per capita (2018) and the poorest is <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> with its US$3,659 per capita (2019). Monaco is the richest country in terms of GDP per capita in the world according to the World Bank report.
As a whole, Europe's GDP per capita is US$21,767 according to a 2016 International Monetary Fund assessment.
Economic history.
Capitalism has been dominant in the Western world since the end of feudalism. From Britain, it gradually spread throughout Europe. The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in Europe, specifically the United Kingdom in the late 18th century, and the 19th century saw Western Europe industrialise. Economies were disrupted by World War I but by the beginning of World War II they had recovered and were having to compete with the growing economic strength of the United States. World War II, again, damaged much of Europe's industries.
After World War II the economy of the UK was in a state of ruin, and continued to suffer relative economic decline in the following decades. Italy was also in a poor economic condition but regained a high level of growth by the 1950s. West Germany <a href="Wirtschaftswunder">recovered quickly</a> and had doubled production from pre-war levels by the 1950s. France also staged a remarkable comeback enjoying rapid growth and modernisation; later on Spain, under the leadership of <a href="Francisco%20Franco">Franco</a>, also recovered and the nation recorded huge unprecedented economic growth beginning in the 1960s in what is called the <a href="Spanish%20miracle">Spanish miracle</a>. The majority of <a href="Central%20and%20Eastern%20Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a>an states came under the control of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and thus were members of the <a href="Council%20for%20Mutual%20Economic%20Assistance">Council for Mutual Economic Assistance</a> (COMECON).
The states which retained a <a href="free-market">free-market</a> system were given a large amount of aid by the United States under the <a href="Marshall%20Plan">Marshall Plan</a>. The western states moved to link their economies together, providing the basis for the EU and increasing cross border trade. This helped them to enjoy rapidly improving economies, while those states in COMECON were struggling in a large part due to the cost of the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>. Until 1990, the <a href="European%20Community">European Community</a> was expanded from 6 founding members to 12. The emphasis placed on resurrecting the West German economy led to it overtaking the UK as Europe's largest economy.
With the fall of communism in Central and Eastern Europe in 1991, the post-socialist states began free market reforms.
After <a href="East%20Germany">East</a> and West Germany were reunited in 1990, the economy of West Germany struggled as it had to support and largely rebuild the infrastructure of East Germany.
By the millennium change, the EU dominated the economy of Europe comprising the five largest European economies of the time namely Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy and Spain. In 1999, 12 of the 15 members of the EU joined the <a href="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> replacing their former national currencies by the common euro. The three who chose to remain outside the Eurozone were: the United Kingdom, Denmark and Sweden. The European Union is now the largest economy in the world.
Figures released by <a href="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> in 2009 confirmed that the Eurozone had gone into <a href="Late%202000s%20recession%20in%20Europe">recession</a> in 2008. It impacted much of the region. In 2010, fears of a <a href="European%20sovereign-debt%20crisis">sovereign debt crisis</a> developed concerning some countries in Europe, especially Greece, Ireland, Spain and Portugal. As a result, measures were taken, especially for Greece, by the leading countries of the Eurozone. The <a href="European%20Union">EU-27</a> unemployment rate was 10.3% in 2012. For those aged 15–24 it was 22.4%.
Demographics.
In 2017, the population of Europe was estimated to be 742 million according to , which is slightly more than one-ninth of the world's population.
A century ago, Europe had nearly a quarter of the <a href="world%20population">world's population</a>. The population of Europe has grown in the past century, but in other areas of the world (in particular Africa and Asia) the population has grown far more quickly. Among the continents, Europe has a relatively high <a href="population%20density">population density</a>, second only to Asia. Most of Europe is in a mode of <a href="Sub-replacement%20fertility">Sub-replacement fertility</a>, which means that each new(-born) generation is being less populous than the older.
The most densely populated country in Europe (and in the world) is the <a href="microstate">microstate</a> of <a href="Monaco">Monaco</a>.
Ethnic groups.
Pan and Pfeil (2004) count 87 distinct "peoples of Europe", of which 33 form the majority population in at least one sovereign state, while the remaining 54 constitute <a href="ethnic%20minority">ethnic minorities</a>.
According to UN population projection, Europe's population may fall to about 7% of world population by 2050, or 653 million people (medium variant, 556 to 777 million in low and high variants, respectively). Within this context, significant disparities exist between regions in relation to <a href="fertility%20rates">fertility rates</a>. The average number of <a href="List%20of%20countries%20and%20territories%20by%20fertility%20rate">children per female</a> of child-bearing age is 1.52. According to some sources, this rate is higher among <a href="Islam%20in%20Europe">Muslims in Europe</a>. The UN predicts a steady <a href="population%20decline">population decline</a> in <a href="Central%20and%20Eastern%20Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a> as a result of emigration and low birth rates.
Migration.
Europe is home to the highest number of migrants of all global regions at 70.6 million people, the <a href="International%20Organisation%20for%20Migration">IOM</a>'s report said. In 2005, the EU had an overall net gain from <a href="immigration">immigration</a> of 1.8 million people. This accounted for almost 85% of Europe's total <a href="population%20growth">population growth</a>. In 2008, 696,000 persons were given citizenship of an EU27 member state, a decrease from 707,000 the previous year. In 2017, approximately 825,000 persons acquired <a href="Citizenship%20of%20the%20European%20Union">citizenship</a> of an EU28 member state. 2.4 million immigrants from non-EU countries entered the EU in 2017.
Early modern <a href="emigration%20from%20Europe">emigration from Europe</a> began with Spanish and Portuguese settlers in the 16th century, and French and English settlers in the 17th century. But numbers remained relatively small until waves of mass emigration in the 19th century, when millions of poor families left Europe.
Today, <a href="European%20diaspora">large populations of European descent</a> are found on every continent. European ancestry predominates in North America and to a lesser degree in South America (particularly in <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, while most of the other <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a>n countries also have a considerable <a href="White%20Latin%20American">population of European origins</a>). <a href="Australia">Australia</a> and <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> have large European-derived populations. Africa has no countries with European-derived majorities (or with the exception of <a href="Cape%20Verde">Cape Verde</a> and probably <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Tom%C3%A9%20and%20Pr%C3%ADncipe">São Tomé and Príncipe</a>, depending on context), but there are significant minorities, such as the <a href="White%20South%20Africans">White South Africans</a> in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. In Asia, European-derived populations, (specifically <a href="Russians">Russians</a>), predominate in <a href="North%20Asia">North Asia</a> and some parts of Northern <a href="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>.
Languages.
Europe has about 225 indigenous languages, mostly falling within three <a href="Indo-European%20languages">Indo-European</a> language groups: the <a href="Romance%20languages">Romance languages</a>, derived from the <a href="Latin%20language">Latin</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a>; the <a href="Germanic%20languages">Germanic languages</a>, whose ancestor language came from southern Scandinavia; and the <a href="Slavic%20languages">Slavic languages</a>. Slavic languages are mostly spoken in Southern, Central and Eastern Europe. Romance languages are spoken primarily in Western and Southern Europe, as well as in <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> in Central Europe and <a href="Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="Moldova">Moldova</a> in Eastern Europe. Germanic languages are spoken in Western, Northern and Central Europe as well as in <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> and <a href="Malta">Malta</a> in Southern Europe. Languages in adjacent areas show significant overlaps (such as in <a href="English%20%28language%29">English</a>, for example). Other Indo-European languages outside the three main groups include the <a href="Baltic%20languages">Baltic</a> group (<a href="Latvian%20language">Latvian</a> and <a href="Lithuanian%20language">Lithuanian</a>), the <a href="Celtic%20languages">Celtic</a> group (<a href="Irish%20language">Irish</a>, <a href="Scots%20Gaelic%20language">Scottish Gaelic</a>, <a href="Manx%20language">Manx</a>, <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh</a>, <a href="Cornish%20language">Cornish</a> and <a href="Breton%20language">Breton</a>), <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>, <a href="Armenian%20language">Armenian</a> and <a href="Albanian%20language">Albanian</a>.
A distinct non-Indo-European family of <a href="Uralic%20languages">Uralic languages</a> (<a href="Estonian%20language">Estonian</a>, <a href="Finnish%20language">Finnish</a>, <a href="Hungarian%20language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="Erzya%20language">Erzya</a>, <a href="Komi%20language">Komi</a>, <a href="Mari%20language">Mari</a>, <a href="Moksha%20language">Moksha</a> and <a href="Udmurt%20language">Udmurt</a>) is spoken mainly in <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> and parts of Russia. <a href="Turkic%20languages">Turkic languages</a> include <a href="Azerbaijani%20language">Azerbaijani</a>, <a href="Kazakh%20language">Kazakh</a> and <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a>, in addition to smaller languages in Eastern and Southeast Europe (<a href="Balkan%20Gagauz%20Turkish">Balkan Gagauz Turkish</a>, <a href="Bashkir%20language">Bashkir</a>, <a href="Chuvash%20language">Chuvash</a>, <a href="Crimean%20Tatar%20language">Crimean Tatar</a>, <a href="Karachay-Balkar%20language">Karachay-Balkar</a>, <a href="Kumyk%20language">Kumyk</a>, <a href="Nogai%20language">Nogai</a> and <a href="Tatar%20language">Tatar</a>). <a href="Kartvelian%20languages">Kartvelian languages</a> (<a href="Georgian%20language">Georgian</a>, <a href="Mingrelian%20language">Mingrelian</a> and <a href="Svan%20language">Svan</a>) are spoken primarily in <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>. Two other language families reside in the North Caucasus (termed <a href="Northeast%20Caucasian%20languages">Northeast Caucasian</a>, most notably including <a href="Chechen%20language">Chechen</a>, <a href="Avar%20language">Avar</a> and <a href="Lezgian%20language">Lezgin</a>; and <a href="Northwest%20Caucasian%20languages">Northwest Caucasian</a>, most notably including <a href="Adyghe%20language">Adyghe</a>). <a href="Maltese%20language">Maltese</a> is the only <a href="Semitic%20language">Semitic language</a> that is official within the EU, while <a href="Basque%20language">Basque</a> is the only European <a href="language%20isolate">language isolate</a>.
Multilingualism and the protection of regional and minority languages are recognised political goals in Europe today. The <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a> <a href="Framework%20Convention%20for%20the%20Protection%20of%20National%20Minorities">Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities</a> and the Council of Europe's <a href="European%20Charter%20for%20Regional%20or%20Minority%20Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a> set up a legal framework for language rights in Europe.
Major cities and urban areas.
The four largest <a href="List%20of%20urban%20areas%20in%20Europe">urban areas of Europe</a> are <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, <a href="London">London</a> and <a href="Paris">Paris</a>. All have over 10 million residents, and as such have been described as <a href="megacity">megacities</a>. While Istanbul has the highest total city population, it lies partly in Asia, making Moscow the <a href="List%20of%20European%20cities%20by%20population%20within%20city%20limits">largest city entirely in Europe</a>.
The next largest cities in order of population are <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> and <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, each having over 3 million residents.
When considering the commuter belts or <a href="List%20of%20metropolitan%20areas%20in%20Europe">metropolitan areas</a>, within the EU (for which comparable data is available) Moscow covers the largest population, followed in order by Istanbul, London, Paris, Madrid, Milan, Ruhr Area, Saint Petersburg, Rhein-Süd, Barcelona and Berlin.
Culture.
"Europe" as a cultural concept is substantially derived from the shared heritage of <a href="ancient%20Greece">ancient Greece</a> and the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a> and its cultures. The boundaries of Europe were historically understood as those of <a href="Christendom">Christendom</a> (or more specifically <a href="Latin%20Christendom">Latin Christendom</a>), as established or defended throughout the medieval and early modern history of Europe, especially <a href="Islamic%20conquests">against Islam</a>, as in the <a href="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> and the <a href="Ottoman%20wars%20in%20Europe">Ottoman wars in Europe</a>.
This shared cultural heritage is combined by overlapping indigenous national cultures and folklores, roughly divided into <a href="Slavic%20Europe">Slavic</a>, <a href="Romance-speaking%20Europe">Latin (Romance)</a> and <a href="Germanic%20Europe">Germanic</a>, but with several components not part of either of these group (notably <a href="Greek%20culture">Greek</a>, <a href="Basque%20culture">Basque</a> and <a href="Celtic%20Europe">Celtic</a>). Historically, special examples with overlapping cultures are <a href="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a> with Latin (Romance) and Germanic or <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> with Latin, Slavic and Germanic roots.
Cultural contacts and mixtures shape a large part of the regional cultures of Europe. It is often described as "maximum cultural diversity with minimal geographical distances".
Different cultural events are organised in Europe, with the aim of bringing different cultures closer together and raising awareness of their importance, such as the <a href="European%20Capital%20of%20Culture">European Capital of Culture</a>, the <a href="European%20Region%20of%20Gastronomy">European Region of Gastronomy</a>, the <a href="European%20Youth%20Capital">European Youth Capital</a> and the European Capital of Sport.
Religion.
<a href="history%20of%20religion">Historically</a>, religion in Europe has been a major influence on <a href="Western%20art%20history">European art</a>, <a href="culture%20of%20Europe">culture</a>, <a href="Western%20philosophy">philosophy</a> and <a href="European%20Union%20law">law</a>. There are six patron saints of Europe venerated in Roman Catholicism, five of them so declared by Pope John Paul II between 1980 and 1999: Saints Cyril and Methodius, Saint Bridget of Sweden, Catherine of Siena and Saint Teresa Benedicta of the Cross (Edith Stein). The exception is Benedict of Nursia, who had already been declared "Patron Saint of all Europe" by Pope Paul VI in 1964.The largest religion in Europe is <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>, with 76.2% of Europeans considering themselves <a href="Christians">Christians</a>, including <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a>, <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> and various <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations. Among Protestants, the most popular are historically state-supported European denominations such as <a href="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a>, <a href="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a> and the <a href="Reformed%20faith">Reformed faith</a>. Other Protestant denominations such as historically significant ones like <a href="Anabaptists">Anabaptists</a> were never supported by any state and thus are not so widespread, as well as these newly arriving from the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> such as <a href="Pentecostalism">Pentecostalism</a>, <a href="Adventism">Adventism</a>, <a href="Methodism">Methodism</a>, <a href="Baptists">Baptists</a> and various <a href="Evangelical%20Protestants">Evangelical Protestants</a>; although Methodism and Baptists both have European origins. The notion of "Europe" and the "<a href="Western%20World">Western World</a>" has been intimately connected with the concept of "<a href="Christendom">Christianity and Christendom</a>"; many even attribute Christianity for being the link that created a unified <a href="European%20identity">European identity</a>.
Historically, Europe has been the centre and "cradle of <a href="Christian%20civilization">Christian civilisation</a>". <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>, including the Roman <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>, has played a prominent role in the shaping of <a href="Western%20civilisation">Western civilisation</a> since at least the 4th century, and for at least a millennium and a half, Europe has been nearly equivalent to <a href="Christian%20culture">Christian culture</a>, even though the religion was inherited from the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>. <a href="Christian%20culture">Christian culture</a> was the predominant force in <a href="western%20civilisation">western civilisation</a>, guiding the course of <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="art">art</a> and <a href="science">science</a>. In 2012 Europe had the <a href="Christianity%20by%20country">world's largest Christian population</a>.
The second most popular religion is <a href="Islam">Islam</a> (6%) concentrated mainly in the Balkans and Eastern Europe (<a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="TRNC">North Cyprus</a>, <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, <a href="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="North%20Caucasus">North Caucasus</a> and the <a href="Idel-Ural">Volga-Ural region</a>). Other religions, including Judaism, <a href="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> and <a href="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> are minority religions (though Tibetan Buddhism is the majority religion of Russia's <a href="Republic%20of%20Kalmykia">Republic of Kalmykia</a>). The 20th century saw the revival of <a href="Neopaganism">Neopaganism</a> through movements such as <a href="Wicca">Wicca</a> and <a href="Druidry">Druidry</a>.
Europe has become a relatively <a href="secular">secular</a> continent, with an increasing number and proportion of <a href="irreligion">irreligious</a>, <a href="atheism">atheist</a> and <a href="agnosticism">agnostic</a> people, who make up about 18.2% of Europe's population, currently the largest secular population in the <a href="Western%20religion">Western world</a>. There are a particularly high number of self-described non-religious people in the Czech Republic, <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>, Sweden, former East Germany and France.
